bestBHT.bht: Jesus teaches his disciples about judgment and forgiveness, urging them to release others from condemnation and not form opinions rashly or unfairly. By forgiving offenses, believers will be forgiven in return. However, this promise is not absolute, as believers themselves may provoke similar judgment if they are excessively severe in their treatment of others. Jesus warns against being judgmental, as it may result in falling under God's righteous condemnation and being treated in the same manner by others.

Henry Alford: The saying is much enriched and expanded here.
Perhaps it was so uttered by our Lord on some other occasion.
The connexion is very strict in Matthew, and would hardly bear this expansion of what is not in that place the leading idea.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 37, 38. See on :-; but this is much fuller and more graphic.
Marvin Vincent: Forgive [απολυετε] . Lit., release. So Rev., Christ exhorts to the opposite of what he has just forbidden : "do not condemn, but release." Compare chapter Luke 22:68; Luke 23:16, Luke 23:17.
John Calvin: This promise, which is added by Luke, means, that the Lord will cause him, who is indulgent, kind, and just to his brethren, to experience the same gentleness from others."
We know that the promises which relate to the present life do not always hold, and are not without exceptions.

Believers themselves, though they endeavor to act justly towards their brethren, are sometimes carried away by excessive severity against brethren...and thus, by their own fault, provoke against themselves a similar judgment.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus does not mean that we are not to form opinions, but not to form them rashly, unfairly, like our prejudice.
Release: Positive command the opposite of the censoriousness condemned.
John Gill: Judge not, and ye shall not be judged... lest you should fall under the righteous censure, judgment, and condemnation of God.
Condemn not, and ye shall not be condemned... lest you should be treated in like manner by others.
Forgive offences and trespasses committed against you, bear with, and pass by injuries and affronts... and ye shall be forgiven.

bhtAttempts.bht: The saying is much enriched and expanded here, as Jesus teaches his disciples about judgment and forgiveness in Luke 6:37. He urges them to release others from condemnation and not form opinions rashly or unfairly. This command is the opposite of the censoriousness that is condemned. By forgiving offenses and trespasses, believers will be forgiven in return. However, this promise is not without exceptions, for believers themselves can sometimes be carried away by excessive severity and provoke similar judgment upon themselves. Jesus warns that if they judge or condemn others, they may fall under the righteous censure and condemnation of God. The connection to Matthew 7:1 emphasizes the importance of not being judgmental in order to avoid being treated in the same manner by others.

In Luke 6:37, Jesus expands on the idea of not judging others, urging his disciples to release them from condemnation. He cautions against forming opinions rashly or unfairly, highlighting the opposite of the condemned censoriousness. By forgiving offenses and trespasses, believers will also be forgiven. However, this promise is not absolute, as believers themselves may provoke similar judgment if they are excessively severe in their treatment of others. The connection to Matthew 7:1 underscores the importance of not being judgmental to avoid reciprocity from others.

Jesus expands on the idea of not judging others in Luke 6:37, urging his disciples to release them from condemnation. By forgiving offenses, believers will be forgiven in return. This promise, however, is not without exceptions, as believers who are excessively severe in their treatment of others may provoke similar judgment upon themselves. Jesus warns against being judgmental, as it may result in falling under God's righteous condemnation and being treated in the same manner by others.

Jesus teaches his disciples about judgment and forgiveness, urging them to release others from condemnation and not form opinions rashly or unfairly. By forgiving offenses, believers will be forgiven in return. However, this promise is not absolute, as believers themselves may provoke similar judgment if they are excessively severe in their treatment of others. Jesus warns against being judgmental, as it may result in falling under God's righteous condemnation and being treated in the same manner by others.

In Luke 6:37, Jesus enriches and expands on the idea of not judging others, urging his disciples to release them from condemnation. By forgiving offenses and trespasses, believers will be forgiven. However, this promise is not without exceptions, as believers themselves may provoke similar judgment by being excessively severe. Jesus warns against being judgmental, as it may result in falling under God's condemnation and being treated likewise by others. The connection to Matthew 7:1 underscores the importance of avoiding judgment to escape reciprocity.
